intro: Ligusticum alatum, commonly known as the winged chervil, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots, parsley, and celery, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small yellow flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and thrives in well-drained soils. Its aromatic leaves and roots have been used in traditional medicine for their purported digestive and anti-inflammatory properties. Ligusticum alatum is also valued in horticulture for its ornamental appeal and ability to attract beneficial insects.
